metadata.title: Effects of smoking and solid-fuel use on COPD, lung cancer, and tuberculosis in China: a time-based, multiple risk factor, modelling study

abstract.text: A risk factor might affect the risk of tuberculosis at different stages of the disease's natural history. In the suscecptible-latent-infectious-recovered model (figure 1 in the main paper and webtable 1), a risk factor can increase the risk of latent infection by increasing the transmission parameter, or that of progression from latent infection to infectious disease by increasing the progression parameter. On the basis of results from recent meta-analyses, 1,2 we used a larger effect size for the association of smoking or indoor air pollution with latent infection (relative risk=1·9 for smoking and 1·4 for indoor air pollution) than with progression (1·5 for smoking and 1·1 for indoor air pollution). In the sensitivity analysis, we varied the relative importance of the effects of smoking on latent infection and on progression. This sensitivity analysis shows that the effects of smoking on TB disease would be larger if smoking has a larger proportional effect on progression than on transmission. The results for optimal DOTS are shown in webfigure 8. This also highlights the need for further research to better differentiate the effects of TB risk factors on transmission versus on progression.

We also analysed the sensitivity of the results to the values of the transmission and progression parameters. For example, in Jiangsu province, we varied the value of transmission parameter around the best-fit value of 1·4, with a range of 0·2-2·2 (the range was obtained by allowing the root mean square of the differences to be three times bigger than that of the best-fit). This range, in turn, led to an estimated 10-36% decline in tuberculosis incidence if both risk factors gradually decline to zero between 2003 and 2033, compared to its best-fit estimate of 24%. We also examined sensitivity to the progression parameter by changing the original value of 0·03 to a range of 0·02-0·04. To match the observed trends of tuberculosis prevalence, lower or higher values of the primary progression parameter are compensated by higher or lower fitted values of transmission parameter. The combined effects of these two changes on the estimated effects of smoking and indoor air pollution are small, because the risk factors affect both latent infection and progression.

We assessed how the uncertainties of multiple model parameters affect the precision of our results. All parameters in webtable 1 were included, except for birth rate and the treatment and transmission parameters. Birth rate is generally exogenous to the effects of most individual diseases and selected to ensure a stable model population. The treatment parameter in retrospective model fitting was based on tuberculosis control history, and in analysis of future tuberculosis incidence varied based on future DOTS scenario (ie, its variation is itself scenario-based as optimum DOTS, moderate DOTS and minimum DOTS; webtable 2). Finally, the transmission parameter was the value fitted to the observed tuberculosis prevalence in China in the main analysis. The range of relative risks for the effect of smoking on transmission was from the recent meta-analysis; 1 for other relative risks we used a range of similar proportion (±16%). The ranges of other parameters came from a fixed percentage change (±25%) of the central values. We used a triangular distribution for each parameter, to give additional weight to the central (best-estimate) value. The distributions of different parameters were treated as independent because they come from different studies.

To estimate the effect of multiparameter uncertainty, we sampled from the joint parameter space to obtain 5000 parameter sets, and repeated the analysis of the seven panels in figure 4 in the main paper for each province and each DOTS scenario 5000 times. The results of this analysis are presented in webtable 5 and show that the interquartile range of the estimated reduction in tuberculosis incidence in 2033 was within 14-33% of its central value in all provinces and in all scenarios of DOTS, smoking, and solid fuel use.

In the main analysis, we used several future scenarios of tuberculosis treatment (webtable 2) and kept the transmission parameter unchanged at the fitted lower bound. It is possible that even higher treatment coverage is achieved in the future (eg, due to a combination of political commitment, improved public health infrastructure, or substantially more effective diagnostic and treatment technologies and methods). We therefore did an analysis with 98% case detection and treatment (eg, under DOTS) coverage in Jiangsu as an example. With such high coverage of DOTS, the benefits of different scenarios of smoking and solid fuel use (measured as proportional reduction in tuberculosis incidence) would range from 8-19%, compared with 10-23% under optimum DOTS (80% coverage), 12-27% under moderate DOTS (50% coverage), and 15-33% under minimum DOTS (20% coverage). body_text.section: Future values of treatment parameter and transmission parameter

body_text.text: Continued declining trend of the transmission parameter, observed in western populations, might even be reversed due to demographic shifts, urbanization, and migration. We assessed this possibility by allowing the transmission parameter in Jiangsu to double over the next 30 years. In this analysis, the benefits of different smoking and solid fuel use (measured as proportional reduction in tuberculosis incidence) would range from 18-37% for optimum DOTS (compared with 10-23% in www.thelancet.com Published online October 4, 2008 Webappendix 3 2 the main analysis), 22-44% for moderate DOTS (compared with 12-27% in the main analysis), and 27-52% for minimum DOTS (compared with 15-33% in the main analysis). In other words, risk factor interventions will have larger proportional (and absolute) effects on tuberculosis when sociodemographic factors favour higher transmission.
